channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: At 82, Emperor Akihito of Japan Wants to Retire. Will Japan Let Him?
item.description: The emperor spoke publicly for the first time about retiring, saying he feared it would become “more difficult” to fulfill his duties.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE

item.title: How a Chinese Man Hoping to Tour Europe Fell Into Germany’s Refugee System
item.media:description: A refugee center in Germany. A Chinese man turned to the German authorities for help after he was robbed of his wallet, but they believed that he was instead seeking help to apply for asylum.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: The man, who apparently traveled to Europe alone speaking only Mandarin, was swept up into Germany’s vast processing system for two weeks.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Indian Activist, Irom Chanu Sharmila, Ends Nearly 16-Year Hunger Strike
item.description: Ms. Sharmila had been force-fed through a tube in her nose while protesting a law shielding members of the military from prosecution. She now plans to run for office.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR and HARI KUMAR
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Putin and Erdogan Vow to Repair Ties as West Watches Nervously
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, right, and President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey arriving on Tuesday for talks at the Constantine Palace in St. Petersburg.
item.description: The symbolism of a meeting in St. Petersburg between the Russian and Turkish presidents was probably enough to raise alarms in Western capitals.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: San Giovanni d'Asso Journal: 2 Towns in Tuscany Ponder a Big Question: Will You Merge With Me?
item.media:description: A fort atop the Italian town of Montalcino. In October, residents there and in neighboring San Giovanni d’Asso will vote on whether to merge the two communities.
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.description: Voters will decide whether San Giovanni d’Asso, which is struggling to deliver basic services, and Montalcino should combine, but there are worries about the loss of local identity.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: What in the World: Who’s Got a Carrier to Rival the U.S. Navy’s? (Hint: Not Russia.)
item.media:description: The French aircraft carrier Charles de Gaulle has played a central role in carrying out airstrikes against the Islamic State in the Middle East.
item.description: To project striking power almost anywhere, it’s hard to beat a nuclear-powered aircraft carrier. Almost all of the 11 in existence are American — almost.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK J. LYONS
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Mexico’s Richest Man Confronts a New Foe: The State That Helped Make Him Rich
item.media:description: Carlos Slim, center, arriving for a meeting in Nicaragua last year. More than half of his cellphone company’s sales now come from outside Mexico.
item.description: Carlos Slim built a business empire that has made him one of the world’s richest men. But Mexico’s leaders have been chipping away at his domain with regulations.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED, RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD and ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Sudden Rainfall Left Little Time to Flee Mudslides in Mexico
item.media:description: Eight people died as this home and the one beside it were destroyed in mudslides in Mexico over the weekend amid torrential rainstorms from Tropical Storm Earl.
item.media:credit: Kirsten Luce for The New York Times
item.description: At least 44 people have died in landslides in the Mexican states of Puebla and Veracruz amid torrential rainstorms from Tropical Storm Earl.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Fighting in Aleppo Leaves 2 Million Without Water, U.N. Says
item.media:description: A man sat behind a broken window in May in a part of Aleppo, Syria, controlled by government forces. Water has been scarce in the city after pumps were damaged in fighting.
item.description: The United Nations implored all sides in the fighting to pause so that aid workers could deliver supplies and fix the water system.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: From Syrian Rubble to German Concert Halls With a Piano, a Mission and Survivor’s Guilt
item.media:description: On a street in Wiesbaden, Germany, a woman recognized Mr. Ahmad from one of his concerts.
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.description: In a nation torn between embracing and fearing the migrants who have arrived in the past year, Aeham Ahmad has set himself the task of putting a human face on his fellow arrivals.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Israel Accuses U.N. Worker of Aiding Hamas in Gaza
item.media:description: The United Nations Development Program headquarters in Gaza City. One of its engineers has been detained by Israel’s internal security agency.
item.description: Prosecutors say a United Nations Development Program engineer used his position to provide material assistance to the Islamist group and its military wing.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Letter From Europe: Restoring Old Churches Inspires a New Philanthropy in Russia
item.media:description: The Orthodox Church of the Nativity in Trubetskoye, Russia, which is being restored with funds raised in charity events held by volunteers.
item.description: Private giving is in its infancy in a country with a history of state control, but church buildings arouse the volunteer spirit.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: Rome Police 'Rescue' Elderly Couple With 2 Plates of Pasta
item.description: Police in a Rome neighborhood have come to the "rescue" of an elderly, quarreling couple by cooking them two plates of pasta.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: ‘The Girl From Ipanema’ Goes Walking Again, With Gisele Bündchen’s Help
item.media:description: Heloísa Pinheiro in 2012. She was the muse for “The Girl From Ipanema.”
item.description: Thanks to the supermodel’s strut during the opening ceremony of the Rio Olympics, the 1963 bossa nova tune has found new life.
item.dc:creator: JONAH ENGEL BROMWICH

item.title: Saudi-Led Coalition Resumes Bombing of Yemeni Capital After Talks Collapse
item.description: Warplanes struck Sana, killing civilians, after the collapse of talks between Houthi rebels and the Saudi-backed government.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: The Interpreter: In Japan, an Emperor Constrained by History and a National Identity Crisis
item.media:description: Emperor Akihito of Japan, right, with Tadamori Oshima, speaker of the lower house of Parliament, in Tokyo this month.
item.description: Since his reign began in 1989, Emperor Akihito has often embodied Japan’s contradiction: a pacifist nation and an imperial past.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER

item.title: U.S. Asks Judge to Deny Turkish Gold Trader’s Motion to Dismiss Charges
item.media:description: Reza Zarrab in 2013.
item.description: Prosecutors disputed the defense’s position that the case against Reza Zarrab, who is charged with conspiring to violate the United States sanctions on Iran, was “a prosecutorial overreach.”
item.dc:creator: BENJAMIN WEISER

item.title: Judge Reopens Complaint Against Argentine Ex-President in 1994 Bombing
item.media:description: Demonstrators in Buenos Aires last month with portraits of victims of a bombing at a Jewish center in 1994.
item.description: The former president, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, had been accused of conspiring to derail an investigation into the bombing of a Jewish center.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN GILBERT

item.title: New Photos Cast Doubt on China’s Vow Not to Militarize Disputed Islands
item.description: Satellite imagery shows China has been building reinforced hangars on the disputed Spratly Islands that can easily accommodate warplanes.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: Center for Strategic and International Studies

item.title: Airstrikes Barely Holding Off Taliban in Helmand, Afghan Officials Say
item.media:description: Afghan security troops in Helmand Province on Saturday. The Taliban have intensified offensive operations in that region of Afghanistan.
item.description: Even as Afghan and American officials insist they will not allow another urban center to fall, the noose is tightening around Lashkar Gah in Helmand Province.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and TAIMOOR SHAH
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Putin and Erdogan, Both Isolated, Reach Out to Each Other
item.description: The Turkish president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, is visiting his Russian counterpart, Vladimir V. Putin, to discuss Syria and trade.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR and TIM ARANGO
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Letter From Europe: For Italians, Donald Trump’s Act Is Familiar
item.media:description: Silvio Berlusconi, center, in 2015. Much has been made in Italy of the similarities between Donald J. Trump and Mr. Berlusconi: Both glorify their success in business, both dominate the media landscape, both boast about their sexual prowess, and both seem to enjoy insulting people and nations.
item.description: ‘‘Tocca a voi’’ is a comment Italians often make to Americans now, meaning ‘‘It is your turn,’’ because Italy was once led by Silvio Berlusconi.
item.dc:creator: CELESTINE BOHLEN

item.title: Longcao Journal: Sneaking Into a Chinese Village Where Floodwater and Unrest Linger
item.media:description: A street in Longcao, China, a week after floods hit last month.
item.description: Some residents of Longcao say the authorities did not issue a warning of a flood on July 19 that killed at least 164 people across two provinces.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER BEAM and XIUZHONG XU

item.title: Edward Daly, Peace-Seeking Bishop in Northern Ireland’s ‘Troubles,’ Dies at 82
item.media:description: Father Edward Daly waving a bloodied white handkerchief in a widely circulated picture from Jan. 30, 1972, known as Bloody Sunday.
item.description: As a priest and later as bishop, he argued relentlessly for peace during the three decades of sectarian violence.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: As Peace Talks in Yemen Crumble, Civilians End Up in Cross Hairs Again
item.media:description: Praying at the graves of children who were killed last week in a Saudi airstrike in Sana, Yemen. United Nations-brokered peace talks have collapsed.
item.description: The Saudi-led coalition is accused of bombing nonmilitary targets, but a United Nations panel said the Houthi rebels had hidden weapons and fighters in residential areas.
item.dc:creator: SHUAIB ALMOSAWA and ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Thailand’s Divisions on Display in Vote Approving New Constitution
item.media:description: Gen. Prayuth Chan-ocha, second from left, the prime minister of Thailand and leader of the junta, in Bangkok on Monday. Initial results showed most voters in the capital and central Thailand favored the proposed constitution, while majorities elsewhere opposed it.
item.description: The proposed charter, which gives the military a powerful role, won strong support in central Thailand but was opposed in the northeast and far south.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.category: National Council for Peace and Order (Thailand)

item.title: Whoops! When Museum Visitors Get Touchy-Feely With the Exhibits and Unleash Mayhem
item.media:description: The wall clock, by the artist James Borden.
item.description: Visitors have defaced, punctured or smashed artifacts, sculptures or paintings by accident or because of a misguided desire to “fix” things.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER MELE

item.title: Thousands in Eastern Chinese City Protest Nuclear Waste Project
item.media:description: Jean-Bernard Lévy, left, chief executive of the French power company EDF, with Qian Zhimin, center, president of the China National Nuclear Corporation, and Philippe Knoche, chief executive of Areva, in Paris last year.
item.description: Officials in Lianyungang emphasized that the plans for a fuel recycling plant had not been completed, after large crowds demonstrated over the weekend.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: 6 South Korean Lawmakers Accused of Taking China’s Side Against Antimissile System
item.media:description: President Park Geun-hye of South Korea accused the opponents of her decision to deploy the American military’s Terminal High-Altitude Area Defense system, or Thaad, of making “absurd arguments that jibe with North Korea’s.”
item.description: They pressed ahead with a Beijing trip, and Korea’s president criticized them for “sympathizing” with the Chinese over the American military’s Terminal High-Altitude Area Defense system.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Suicide Bomber Kills Dozens at Pakistani Hospital in Quetta
item.media:description: Mourners on Monday after the hospital attack in Quetta. The blast occurred shortly after the body of a prominent lawyer, killed by gunmen earlier in the day, had been transferred to the hospital.
item.description: A lawyers’ group had gathered to condemn the killing of a prominent colleague only hours earlier in the violence-torn city in Baluchistan Province.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Sinosphere: Reconstructing Taoism’s Transformation in China
item.media:description: A Taoist nun at the Beichan Temple in Xining, in the Chinese province of Qinghai.
item.description: Terry F. Kleeman has published the first book in a Western language on the founding of Taoism as a formal religion, rooted in earlier philosophical texts.
item.dc:creator: IAN JOHNSON

item.title: What in the World: Put One Foot Wrong in This Town and You’ve Left the Country
item.description: Borders dating to the 12th century carve Baarle into a crazy patchwork, splitting sidewalks, shops and houses between Belgium and the Netherlands.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN

item.title: Kenya Angers Taiwan by Deporting More Fraud Suspects to China
item.media:description: Suspects in court in Nairobi, Kenya, last week before their acquittals in a telephone fraud case. Forty of the defendants, five of them from Taiwan, have since been deported to mainland China.
item.description: Taiwan said the deportations of five of its people to the mainland, which followed similar ones in April, showed “contempt for human rights.”
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: 5 Things to Know About Japan’s Emperor and Imperial Family
item.media:description: Emperor Hirohito, the father of Emperor Akihito.
item.description: The oldest continuous monarchy in the world, extending back to 600 B.C., has had an unbroken hereditary line of 125 emperors.
item.dc:creator: RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: These Days of Rage
item.media:description: Police tape outlined the scene in Ansbach, in southern Germany, where a man blew himself up last month.
item.description: The real terror of today’s terrorism is that it is so mindless and random, without political object.
item.dc:creator: KENAN MALIK
item.category: Dallas, Tex, Shooting of Police Officers (2016)

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: A Seismic Shock for Jacob Zuma
item.media:description: Residents of Diepsloot township, north of Johannesburg, line up to cast their votes last week in local government elections across South Africa.
item.description: The poor showing of his African National Congress party in local elections represents a political earthquake in South Africa.
item.dc:creator: MARK GEVISSER

item.title: Editorial: Time to Get Serious With South Sudan
item.media:description: South Sudanese from the city of Malakal took refuge behind the walls of the United Nations compound there.
item.description: The United Nations Security Council should impose an embargo on arms shipments as part of a solution to end the killing and other abuses.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Talking to Terrorists
item.media:description: Harry Sarfo, a former Islamic State fighter from Germany, inside the maximum-security prison in Bremen where he is serving a three-year sentence on terrorism charges.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: For once, the conversation wasn’t via social media, and the name the Islamic State defector used was the one on his birth certificate.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Outstanding Issues: A Yemeni Teenager’s Trip to Estonia, by Way of Guantánamo
item.media:description: Ahmed Abdul Qader, a former Guantánamo Bay detainee, at Freedom Square in Tallinn, Estonia, in May.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: The reporter Charlie Savage wrote about an ex-Guantánamo inmate’s resettlement; the story didn’t end when the article published.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: At the Front in a Scarred Falluja
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Bryan Denton, a photographer who works for The New York Times and is based in Beirut, Lebanon, gives his account of covering Iraqi forces’ recapture of Falluja from the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: BRYAN DENTON
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT

item.title: Not Forgotten: Inside The Times Archives
item.description: Since 1851, more than 200,000 people have been the subjects of obituaries in The New York Times. Join us each day this summer as we revisit many of these memorable lives.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Voices From Europe’s Far Right
item.media:description: “Our economy doesn’t increase along with the never-ending supply of immigrants,” wrote Mikael Jakobsen, 24, a law student in Aarhus, Denmark.
item.media:credit: Michael Drost-Hansen for The New York Times
item.description: Hundreds of readers from across the Continent responded to our call to share their experiences as supporters of far-right parties.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ
